I find the vehicle to be every bit an equal to that of Maserati -perhaps even a little better in terms of design and features -and a tick below Ferrari in terms of overall cache. That being said, I believe Alfa has positioned itself to be a real star of the Fiat brand portfolio as it retains all of what makes Ferrari feel or seem special, with the more mainstream creature comforts Maserati brings to the table all the while being affordable (relatively speaking). I was shocked at just how much Alfa gives its customers for the money. Even fully loaded, I think Alfas are more than reasonably priced compared to the competition. I have been a Mercedes customer for nearly 15 years now and if it weren't for a downturn in their quality controls and customer service, I likely still would be. Since we had already purchased a Stelvio from them, I went back to them when my wife and I decided that we probably would not be able to get by with just one car and enjoyed working with all the people at Alfa Romeo of San Diego. My Stelvio Salesman showed me the i3 and after we had discussed it and other electric cars, he told me that they had some very good deals on 2017 Giulias if I would consider one of them. He knew that I had looked at them before, but he show me the models that they had and I sat it one again and felt that it might be workable. The most exciting thing about considering it, the price not withstanding, was that we would have two cars that could be driven interchangeably between my wife and I with the same safety features and performance and with the same control panels. I spent a couple of days considering and after some long discussions with my wife we decided to lease the Giulia for the next 3 years and decide then about whether or not we continue to need two cars or not.  We took the Giulia on a 500 mile trip the next weekend and driving it was a blast. Everyone thinks that it is a beautiful car and when I tell them that it costs much less than comparable performance models from other makes they are very impressed. Read the comments I made in my Stelvio survey below if you want my background with Cars I have been driving relatively high performance cars for nearly 60 years. During that time I have owned GTO's (1964), BMWs (1969 2002, 1977 630 CSi, 1984 733i), Lancia Beta Sedan (1976), Audi 5000 (1978), MB (1984 500SEC, !986 300E, 1986 560 SEL, !988 560 SEL,1988 300CE, 1991 500 SL, 2005 VW Phaeton, and 2007 VW Eos 3.2. After driving the VW Phaeton and Eos for more than ten years each, my wife and I began to feel that we needed some of the new, more advanced safety advances that have begun to be offered in the last couple of years. I decided to look at the Giulia, which I thought felt a little small and then when I read about Stelvio, I decided to wait to buy and take a look at it before I made any final decision. Meanwhile I looked at BMW, MB, and Audi the Kia Stinger and Hyundai Genesis and even the Lincoln Continental. I also looked at Tesla, Kia Soul EV and VW Golf EV. When the Stelvio finally came in, I drove it, sat in it and mentally compared it to all the other car models I had driven. I decided then that the Stelvio would be the car for me to buy. My wife also liked and the performance and felt that she would not minding driving it as it wasn't really that much bigger than her Eos. I wanted to buy the Stelvio TI with the Safety Equipment and the  Lusso Package and was willing to place the order and wait for it to be built. There was no word from AR to the dealer as when orders for the Lusso could be placed, so I waited until I could find a Stelvio TI without all the extras, but with the Safety features and we finally found one that was as close as I could get, really with only the Navigation package in addition to the Safety features. Bought it in early December 2017 and have be very happy with the performance and the fact that I don't see one on every corner like I do Q5s, X1s,and X3s, and GLCs. I didn't really start out looking for an SUV, but am really happy with everything about it. It has a simple elegance inside and out.
